description: VFG013276(gb|WP_010868969) (opsX/rfaC) heptosyltransferase I  [LOS (VF0044) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Haemophilus influenzae Rd KW20]

It is an integral membrane protein localized to the cytoplasmic membrane, with multiple transmembrane domains that anchor it to the inner membrane, and a large periplasmic domain that houses the catalytic site. The protein should exhibit structural features typical of processive glycosyltransferases, including a Rossmann-like fold for ADP-heptose binding and specific residues for coordinating the sugar donor and acceptor substrates. The sequence must ensure proper integration into the membrane and correct orientation of the active site toward the periplasmic space where LOS assembly occurs. The functional integrity of this enzyme is crucial for Haemophilus influenzae pathogenesis, as defects in LOS biosynthesis impair bacterial survival in the host and reduce virulence by compromising immune evasion mechanisms.

This protein functions as a key virulence factor by synthesizing and modifying the lipid A and core oligosaccharide components of LPS, which is essential for immune modulation and bacterial survival. BplI is involved in the transfer of specific sugar moieties during LPS assembly, contributing to the structural integrity and endotoxic properties of the outer membrane. The protein likely contains conserved glycosyltransferase domains, transmembrane helices for membrane association, and catalytic residues for sugar nucleotide binding and transfer. It operates within the LPS biosynthesis pathway, interacting with other enzymes to construct the complete LPS molecule, which plays a crucial role in evading host immune responses and establishing infection. The sequence should reflect these functional characteristics, including appropriate domain architecture, membrane-spanning regions, and active sites for enzymatic activity.

description: VFG002017(gb|WP_010947516) (fliO) flagellar protein FliO [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Design a complete protein sequence for the flagellar protein FliO from Legionella pneumophila, a critical component of the bacterial flagellar export apparatus. This protein functions as an essential virulence factor that enables bacterial motility, chemotaxis, and host colonization. FliO is an integral membrane protein that forms part of the flagellar type III secretion system (fT3SS) export gate complex, specifically interacting with FliP, FliQ, and FliR to facilitate the selective transport of flagellar structural subunits from the cytoplasm to the growing flagellar structure. The protein should contain a single transmembrane domain spanning the inner membrane, with both N- and C-terminal regions facing the cytoplasm. Key structural features include conserved hydrophobic regions for membrane insertion and specific interaction domains for complex formation with other export apparatus components. The sequence should reflect the characteristic features of flagellar export proteins in Gram-negative bacteria, including appropriate amino acid composition for membrane integration and protein-protein interaction interfaces. The resulting protein must be functionally competent to participate in the hierarchical assembly of the flagellar basal body and enable the efficient export of flagellin and other hook-associated proteins, thereby contributing to the swimming motility essential for Legionella pneumophila's pathogenesis and environmental persistence.

description: VFG049911(gb|WP_000393837) (tssF) Type VI secretion system protein TssF [T6SS (VF0579) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Shigella sonnei Ss046]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the Type VI secretion system protein TssF from Shigella sonnei, a Gram-negative bacterial pathogen responsible for shigellosis. TssF is part of the T6SS membrane complex, specifically interacting with TssE and TssG to form the baseplate wedge subcomplex that anchors the contractile sheath-tube structure to the inner membrane. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of TssF family members, including helical bundle structures that mediate protein-protein interactions within the baseplate assembly. It should feature transmembrane regions or membrane-associated domains for proper localization to the bacterial inner membrane, and conserved motifs that facilitate its role in sheath polymerization and effector protein loading. The sequence must maintain the structural integrity required for baseplate formation, sheath attachment, and the contractile mechanism that drives effector translocation across bacterial and target cell membranes during infection.

description: VFG000381(gb|WP_002212981) (lcrV) type III secretion system hydrophilic translocator, needle tip protein LcrV [TTSS (VF0140) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Yersinia pestis CO92]

Structurally, LcrV should feature an N-terminal coiled-coil domain for needle tip attachment, a central globular domain with immunomodulatory properties capable of interacting with host Toll-like receptors, and a C-terminal region involved in pore formation. The sequence must maintain key functional motifs for calcium-responsive regulation and effector protein translocation control, while exhibiting the characteristic hydrophilicity required for its extracellular positioning and host interface functions. description: VFG003530(gb|WP_011817137) (YE_RS17800) hypothetical protein [Ysa TTSS (VF1025) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Yersinia enterocolitica subsp. enterocolitica 8081]

description: VFG045516(gb|WP_010946888) (ravQ) Dot/Icm type IV secretion system effector RavQ [Dot/Icm T4SS secreted effectors (VF0798) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]

description: VFG039146(gb|NP_820612) (icmL.2/dotI) Type IVB secretion system protein IcmL [Dot/Icm T4SS (VF0503) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Coxiella burnetii RSA 493]

description: VFG038374(gb|WP_011705709) (atsB) Type VI secretion system protein [T6SS (VF0480) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Aeromonas hydrophila subsp. hydrophila ATCC 7966]
prompt: Design a complete protein sequence for the AtsB protein from Aeromonas hydrophila, a critical component of the Type VI Secretion System (T6SS). As part of the T6SS effector delivery machinery, AtsB plays an essential role in the assembly and function of the secretion apparatus, which is responsible for injecting toxic effector proteins directly into target eukaryotic cells. The protein likely contains conserved domains characteristic of T6SS structural components, such as those involved in forming the contractile sheath or baseplate complex. description: VFG050874(gb|WP_001989189.1) (gspL) general secretion pathway protein L [T2SS (VF1335) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Acinetobacter baumannii ACICU]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for GspL, a core component of the Type II Secretion System (T2SS) from the opportunistic pathogen Acinetobacter baumannii. description: VFG049910(gb|WP_000348788) (tssG) Type VI secretion system protein TssG [T6SS (VF0579) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Shigella sonnei Ss046]

TssG is part of the conserved TssF-TssG-TssE subcomplex that forms the baseplate structure, serving as an essential assembly platform for the T6SS tail tube and sheath. description: VFG013286(gb|WP_005694325) (galE) UDP-glucose 4-epimerase [LOS (VF0044) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Haemophilus influenzae Rd KW20]
prompt: Design a functionally accurate protein sequence for UDP-glucose 4-epimerase (GalE) from Haemophilus influenzae strain Rd KW20, a critical virulence factor in this human respiratory pathogen. description: VFG000025(gb|WP_010929995) (cyaA) bifunctional hemolysin-adenylate cyclase precursor [CyaA/ACT (VF0028) - Exotoxin (VFC0235)] [Bordetella pertussis Tohama I]

The adenylate cyclase domain must be activated by host calmodulin binding, featuring the characteristic calmodulin-binding motif that enables calcium-dependent regulation. The protein should adopt a multi-domain architecture where the adenylate cyclase activity becomes functional only after translocation into the host cytosol, while the hemolysin activity contributes to initial membrane disruption. description: VFG000825(gb|WP_001002833) (escT) Type III secretion system minor export apparatus protein EscT [TTSS (VF0191) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Escherichia coli O157:H7 str. EDL933]

description: VFG000977(gb|WP_002985285) (sagA) streptolysin S associated protein [SLS (VF0251) - Exotoxin (VFC0235)] [Streptococcus pyogenes M1 GAS]

description: VFG000041(gb|WP_010930815) (bscU) Bordetella Bsc type III secretion system protein BscU [TTSS (VF0035) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Bordetella pertussis Tohama I]

description: VFG053443(gb|WP_095907672.1) (flgF) flagellar basal body rod protein FlgF [Flagella (VF1400) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Enterobacter cloacae strain M12X01451]

description: VFG050889(gb|WP_000783000.1) (gspM) general secretion pathway protein M [T2SS (VF1335) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Acinetobacter baumannii ACICU]

description: VFG045517(gb|WP_010946900) (ravR) Dot/Icm type IV secretion system effector RavR [Dot/Icm T4SS secreted effectors (VF0798) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]

description: VFG045519(gb|WP_010946917) (ravS) Dot/Icm type IV secretion system effector RavS [Dot/Icm T4SS secreted effectors (VF0798) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]

description: VFG006637(gb|WP_001085308) (motB) flagellar motor protein [Flagella (VF0051) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Helicobacter pylori 26695]

description: VFG002549(gb|WP_004527663) (wcbQ) capsular polysaccharide biosynthesis transmembrane protein [Capsule I (VF0436) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Burkholderia pseudomallei K96243]

description: VFG042789(gb|WP_012477166) (bfpD) assembly ATPase [BFP (VF0174) - Adherence (VFC0001)] [Escherichia coli O127:H6 str. E2348/69]

description: VFG002449(gb|WP_004203135) (bipC) Type III secretion system translocator protein BipC [Bsa T3SS (VF0428) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Burkholderia pseudomallei K96243]

description: VFG002018(gb|WP_010947517) (fliN) flagellar motor switch protein FliN [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]

description: VFG049905(gb|WP_000343289) (tssL) Type VI secretion system protein TssL [T6SS (VF0579) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Shigella sonnei Ss046]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the Type VI secretion system protein TssL from Shigella sonnei, a Gram-negative bacterial pathogen responsible for bacillary dysentery. This protein functions as a critical structural component of the Type VI secretion system (T6SS), a contractile nanomachine that delivers effector proteins directly into target cells. TssL serves as an essential membrane-anchored subunit of the T6SS baseplate complex, forming part of the trans-envelope assembly that spans both the inner and outer membranes. The protein should contain a single transmembrane domain near its N-terminus for proper membrane integration, followed by a large cytoplasmic domain that interacts with other T6SS components including TssM, TssK, and the TssJ outer membrane lipoprotein. The cytoplasmic region should feature conserved helical bundles and protein-protein interaction interfaces essential for baseplate assembly and stability. The sequence must maintain key conserved residues for oligomerization and for forming the interface with the TssM protein, which together create the membrane-spanning complex. The overall structure should facilitate the proper assembly of the contractile sheath and spike apparatus, enabling the injection of toxic effectors into eukaryotic host cells during Shigella pathogenesis. The generated sequence should reflect the characteristic features of bacterial T6SS membrane components while maintaining functional specificity for Shigella virulence.

description: VFG000032(gb|WP_010929610) (bplG) probable sugar transferase [LPS (VF0033) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Bordetella pertussis Tohama I]
prompt: Design a functionally correct protein sequence for a sugar transferase virulence factor from Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough. This enzyme plays a critical role in lipopolysaccharide (LPS) biosynthesis, specifically in the modification of the core oligosaccharide or O-antigen component. As a key virulence determinant, it contributes to immune modulation by altering the surface properties of the bacterial outer membrane, thereby enhancing resistance to host complement-mediated killing and modulating Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) signaling. The protein should contain conserved glycosyltransferase domains, likely adopting a GT-B fold architecture characterized by two distinct Rossmann-fold domains separated by a deep catalytic cleft. Key structural motifs should include a nucleotide-sugar binding pocket with conserved DXD or related motifs for coordinating divalent cations (typically Mn²⁺ or Mg²⁺), and a hydrophobic membrane-associated region for proper localization to the cytoplasmic membrane or periplasmic face. The enzyme should demonstrate specificity for sugar nucleotide donors (potentially UDP-glucose, UDP-galactose, or similar) and acceptor LPS substrates, facilitating the transfer of sugar moieties to growing LPS molecules. The resulting protein should maintain optimal stability for function in the bacterial envelope environment while enabling the pathogen to evade innate immune recognition through strategic LPS modifications.

description: VFG006986(gb|WP_000828585) (mshA) MSHA pilin protein MshA [MSHA pili (VF0515) - Adherence (VFC0001)] [Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar El Tor str. N16961]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the MSHA pilin protein MshA from Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar El Tor strain N16961. This protein serves as the major structural subunit of the mannose-sensitive hemagglutinin (MSHA) type IV pili, which are critical virulence factors for bacterial adherence and colonization in the human host. The MSHA pili mediate attachment to intestinal epithelial cells through specific recognition of mannose-containing receptors on host cell surfaces, facilitating the initial stages of cholera infection. The MshA protein should contain conserved domains and motifs characteristic of type IV pilins, including an N-terminal hydrophobic transmembrane helix that anchors the protein in the inner membrane prior to assembly, a conserved disulfide-bonded region in the C-terminal domain that stabilizes the pilus structure, and specific receptor-binding residues that confer mannose sensitivity. The protein must be capable of polymerization into helical pilus filaments through hydrophobic interactions between N-terminal domains, while exposing the C-terminal receptor-binding domain on the pilus surface. The sequence should reflect the structural requirements for pilus assembly machinery recognition and should maintain the amphipathic character necessary for both membrane integration and extracellular filament formation. The generated protein must be functional for host cell adhesion while evading immediate immune recognition, supporting Vibrio cholerae's pathogenesis in the human gastrointestinal tract.

description: VFG048985(gb|WP_014907219) (KP1_RS17355) phosphatase PAP2 family protein [Capsule (VF0560) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Klebsiella pneumoniae subsp. pneumoniae NTUH-K2044]
prompt: Design a functional phosphatase enzyme from Klebsiella pneumoniae, a significant human pathogen known for causing hospital-acquired infections including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bacteremia, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. This protein belongs to the PAP2 (phosphatidic acid phosphatase type 2) family and functions as a virulence factor involved in capsule biosynthesis and immune modulation. The enzyme should contain characteristic PAP2 family domains with conserved active site motifs, likely featuring multiple transmembrane helices typical of membrane-associated phosphatases. It should exhibit specificity for lipid phosphate substrates, potentially participating in the modification of capsule polysaccharides or membrane components to evade host immune recognition. The protein's mechanism involves dephosphorylation reactions that alter bacterial surface properties, contributing to immune evasion by interfering with complement activation or phagocytosis. Structural features should include the conserved phosphatase catalytic domain with essential histidine and aspartate residues in the active site, arranged in a membrane-integrated conformation that facilitates interaction with lipid substrates. The protein functions within the capsule biosynthesis pathway, modifying intermediates to produce the complete capsular polysaccharide that protects the bacterium from host defenses.

description: VFG000026(gb|WP_010931478) (dnt) dermonecrotic toxin [Dnt (VF0029) - Exotoxin (VFC0235)] [Bordetella pertussis Tohama I]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for the dermonecrotic toxin (Dnt) from Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough. This potent exotoxin functions as a critical virulence factor by inducing localized tissue necrosis and systemic toxicity through its ADP-ribosyltransferase activity. The protein should feature a catalytic domain with conserved residues for NAD+ binding and ADP-ribosylation, specifically targeting host cell Rho GTPases to disrupt cytoskeletal organization and signal transduction pathways. Include structural motifs characteristic of bacterial ADP-ribosylating toxins, such as a catalytic glutamic acid residue and key arginine residues involved in substrate recognition. The protein should possess appropriate signal sequences for secretion and maintain the characteristic multi-domain architecture that facilitates host cell recognition, membrane translocation, and enzymatic activity. Ensure the sequence reflects the thermostability and protease resistance typical of bacterial exotoxins while maintaining the conformational flexibility required for membrane penetration and intracellular delivery.

description: VFG000037(gb|WP_003807114) (bplB) probable acetyltransferase [LPS (VF0033) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Bordetella pertussis Tohama I]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for a bacterial acetyltransferase that functions as a key virulence factor in Bordetella pertussis, the causative agent of whooping cough. This protein, designated bplB, plays a critical role in immune modulation through lipopolysaccharide (LPS) modification. The enzyme should catalyze the transfer of acetyl groups to specific positions on the LPS core or lipid A moiety, thereby altering the host immune recognition and reducing Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4)-mediated inflammatory responses. The protein should contain conserved acetyltransferase domains, including characteristic motifs for acetyl-CoA binding and catalytic residues essential for acetyl group transfer. It should exhibit structural features typical of bacterial acetyltransferases, with a well-defined active site pocket capable of accommodating both the acetyl-CoA donor and LPS acceptor substrates. The protein should be localized to the bacterial inner membrane or periplasmic space to facilitate access to the LPS biosynthesis pathway. Include appropriate signal sequences or membrane association domains if required for proper localization and function. The overall structure should maintain stability in the bacterial envelope environment while enabling efficient interaction with LPS substrates and cofactors.

description: VFG038371(gb|WP_011705707) (vgrG2) VgrG protein [T6SS (VF0480) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Aeromonas hydrophila subsp. hydrophila ATCC 7966]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the VgrG2 protein from Aeromonas hydrophila subsp. hydrophila ATCC 7966, a critical component of the Type VI Secretion System (T6SS) effector delivery machinery. This protein functions as a structural and functional component of the T6SS nanomachine, serving as both a puncturing device and a carrier for effector proteins. The VgrG2 protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of the VgrG family, including an N-terminal domain that integrates with the T6SS baseplate complex, a central trimeric coiled-coil region that forms the rigid spike structure, and a C-terminal domain that may serve as an effector domain or facilitate effector protein loading. The protein should exhibit structural features enabling it to penetrate target cell membranes during T6SS firing, with specific motifs for interaction with other T6SS components such as Hcp and the membrane complex. The sequence should reflect the protein's role in bacterial virulence, including features that enable it to withstand the mechanical forces during membrane penetration and maintain structural integrity within the T6SS apparatus. Consider the protein's subcellular localization to the bacterial envelope and its assembly into the T6SS contractile sheath structure. The generated sequence must be functionally competent for its dual role as both a structural component of the secretion apparatus and a delivery vehicle for virulence effectors.

description: VFG002016(gb|WP_010947515) (fliP) flagellar biosynthetic protein FliP [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the flagellar biosynthetic protein FliP from Legionella pneumophila, a critical component in the assembly of the bacterial flagellum, which is essential for motility, chemotaxis, and virulence in this opportunistic human pathogen. FliP functions as part of the flagellar type III secretion system (fT3SS) export apparatus, specifically forming a transmembrane ring complex within the inner membrane that facilitates the selective translocation of flagellar structural subunits (e.g., rod, hook, and filament proteins) from the cytoplasm to the growing flagellar structure. The protein must contain multiple transmembrane helices to anchor it in the inner membrane, conserved domains typical of FliP family proteins (e.g., involved in substrate recognition and export), and key residues for interactions with other export apparatus components like FliQ and FliR. Its mechanism involves ATP-independent protein export driven by the proton motive force, contributing directly to Legionella's ability to navigate aqueous environments, infect alveolar macrophages, and cause Legionnaires' disease. Ensure the sequence reflects a bacterial protein with no eukaryotic motifs, appropriate hydrophobicity for membrane integration, and functional regions supporting its role in the stepwise assembly of the flagellar basal body and axial components.

description: VFG048030(gb|WP_003022143) (pdpC) Type VI secretion system secreted protein PdpC [T6SS secreted effectors (VF1193) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis SCHU S4]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the PdpC protein, a critical Type VI Secretion System (T6SS) effector from Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis SCHU S4. This pathogen is the causative agent of tularemia, a severe zoonotic disease, and relies on the T6SS for intracellular survival and virulence. PdpC functions as a secreted effector protein that is translocated into host cells via the T6SS apparatus to subvert host immune defenses and facilitate bacterial replication within macrophages. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of T6SS effectors, including a C-terminal domain for interaction with the T6SS spike complex and potential N-terminal functional domains involved in host cell modulation. The sequence must feature appropriate secretion signals for T6SS-mediated export, likely through interaction with the VgrG or PAAR proteins, and structural motifs that enable membrane association or cytosolic targeting. The protein should adopt a compact, globular fold with surface-exposed regions for host protein interactions, potentially mimicking eukaryotic domains to interfere with signaling pathways. Ensure the sequence reflects the high pathogenicity of this Francisella strain and its adaptation for evasion of phagolysosomal fusion, promoting bacterial escape into the host cytosol.

description: VFG002025(gb|YP_002344527) (htrB) lipid A biosynthesis lauroyl acyltransferase [LOS (VF0326) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for HtrB, a critical virulence factor from Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168. This protein functions as a lauroyl acyltransferase in the lipid A biosynthesis pathway, specifically catalyzing the transfer of laurate (C12:0) to the Kdo2-lipid IVA intermediate during lipooligosaccharide (LOS) assembly. HtrB is an integral membrane protein localized to the inner bacterial membrane, featuring multiple transmembrane helices and a conserved acyltransferase domain with a characteristic HX4D motif essential for catalytic activity. As a key enzyme in LOS modification, HtrB contributes to immune modulation by altering the endotoxic properties of lipid A, enhancing bacterial resistance to host antimicrobial peptides and promoting immune evasion. The protein should exhibit structural characteristics typical of Gram-negative bacterial acyltransferases, including membrane-embedded regions for substrate recognition and a cytoplasmic catalytic domain for acyl chain transfer. Design this enzyme to maintain optimal activity at physiological temperatures relevant to human gastrointestinal colonization.

description: VFG000225(gb|WP_002221781) (pilS) pilin [Type IV pili (VF0075) - Adherence (VFC0001)] [Neisseria meningitidis MC58]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the PilS protein from Neisseria meningitidis strain MC58, a key transcriptional regulator in the type IV pilus biogenesis system. This protein functions as a response regulator within a two-component signal transduction system, specifically responding to environmental cues to control the expression of pilin and other pilus-associated genes. PilS is part of the PilS/PilR regulatory pair, where it acts as the sensor histidine kinase that autophosphorylates upon detecting specific signals, then transfers the phosphate group to its cognate response regulator PilR, which subsequently activates transcription of pilus operons. The protein should contain characteristic domains of bacterial sensor kinases: an N-terminal transmembrane domain for signal perception and localization to the inner membrane, a central HAMP domain for signal transduction, and a C-terminal histidine kinase domain featuring the conserved H-box, N-box, G-box, and F-box motifs essential for ATP binding and autophosphorylation at the conserved histidine residue. The structural organization should facilitate dimerization through the histidine kinase domain, with the periplasmic sensor domain likely containing recognition sites for environmental stimuli that modulate pilus expression in response to host contact or other virulence-associated conditions. The generated sequence must reflect the functional requirements for proper membrane integration, signal transduction, and phosphorylation activity that enables Neisseria meningitidis to dynamically regulate type IV pilus expression during colonization and invasion of human mucosal surfaces.

description: VFG003531(gb|WP_011817138) (ysaI) type III secretion system inner rod subunit SctI [Ysa TTSS (VF1025) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Yersinia enterocolitica subsp. enterocolitica 8081]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for the YsaI protein, the inner rod subunit of the Yersinia enterocolitica type III secretion system (T3SS). This protein is a critical structural component of the Ysa T3SS, a specialized macromolecular complex that functions as a molecular syringe to inject bacterial effector proteins directly into host cells. YsaI forms the inner rod structure that spans the periplasmic space within the T3SS needle complex, providing structural stability and serving as a conduit for effector protein translocation. The protein should contain conserved coiled-coil domains typical of T3SS inner rod subunits, facilitating protein-protein interactions with other T3SS components including the needle filament protein and the export apparatus. The sequence should reflect the characteristic features of gram-negative bacterial virulence factors, including an N-terminal secretion signal for T3SS-mediated export and regions optimized for assembly into a hollow, helical rod structure. The mature protein should be approximately 20-30 kDa with amphipathic regions that enable membrane association and complex formation. The structural organization should support its role in maintaining the integrity of the secretion channel while allowing the passage of unfolded effector proteins during the injection process.

description: VFG006647(gb|WP_000963306) (flgD) flagellar basal-body rod modification protein FlgD [Flagella (VF0051) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Helicobacter pylori 26695]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for the flagellar basal-body rod modification protein FlgD from Helicobacter pylori strain 26695. This protein is a critical virulence factor that functions within the flagellar biosynthesis pathway, enabling bacterial motility and colonization in the hostile gastric environment. FlgD specifically modifies the basal-body rod structure during flagellar assembly, ensuring proper rod elongation and structural integrity for the rotating flagellar motor. The protein likely contains conserved domains involved in rod protein recognition, peptidoglycan interaction for rod penetration through the cell envelope, and enzymatic motifs for post-translational modifications. It should exhibit structural characteristics compatible with its localization at the cell envelope interface, including regions for membrane association and protein-protein interactions with other basal-body components like FlgB, FlgC, and FlgF. The sequence must maintain functional motifs essential for rod modification activity while preserving the overall stability required for its role in constructing the bacterial motility apparatus that facilitates Helicobacter pylori pathogenesis in the human stomach.

description: VFG013346(gb|WP_005693178) (galU) glucosephosphate uridylyltransferase [LOS (VF0044) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Haemophilus influenzae Rd KW20]
prompt: Design a glucosephosphate uridylyltransferase (GalU) protein from Haemophilus influenzae strain Rd KW20, a significant human respiratory pathogen that causes otitis media, bronchitis, and invasive diseases like meningitis. This enzyme serves as a critical virulence factor by synthesizing UDP-glucose, an essential precursor for lipooligosaccharide (LOS) biosynthesis. LOS functions as a major surface antigen and potent immune modulator that enables bacterial evasion of host immune responses through molecular mimicry of host glycolipids. The GalU enzyme should exhibit the characteristic structural architecture of nucleotidyltransferase family proteins, featuring a conserved Rossmann-fold domain for NAD+ binding and catalytic activity. Include the essential catalytic residues responsible for the reversible transfer of uridyl groups between UTP and glucose-1-phosphate, generating UDP-glucose. The protein should maintain proper oligomeric state, likely forming a functional homodimer or homotetramer with active sites at subunit interfaces. Ensure the sequence contains all necessary motifs for substrate recognition, including the sugar-phosphate binding pocket and nucleotide triphosphate coordination sites. The enzyme must demonstrate optimal activity under physiological conditions relevant to the human respiratory tract environment, with appropriate thermal stability and pH sensitivity for its role in LOS assembly and immune modulation.

description: VFG048002(gb|WP_003022141) (iglJ) Type VI secretion system protein IglJ [T6SS (VF0544) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis SCHU S4]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the IglJ protein, a critical component of the Type VI Secretion System (T6SS) from Francisella tularensis subspecies tularensis strain SCHU S4. This protein functions as an essential virulence factor in one of the most infectious bacterial pathogens known, responsible for tularemia. IglJ operates within the T6SS effector delivery machinery, specifically contributing to the assembly and function of the contractile phage tail-like structure that injects toxic effector proteins directly into host cells. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of T6SS components, likely including helical bundle structures for protein-protein interactions and membrane association motifs. It should exhibit structural features enabling integration into the T6SS baseplate or sheath complex, with specific interfaces for binding partner proteins like IglI and other T6SS core components. The sequence must reflect the acidic intracellular pH adaptation typical of Francisella proteins and include regions for proper folding, stability, and interaction with the T6SS membrane complex. The protein should be soluble and localized to the bacterial cytoplasm when not assembled into the secretion apparatus, with specific motifs enabling its recruitment to the inner membrane for T6SS assembly. Include conserved residues critical for maintaining the structural integrity of the T6SS machinery and for facilitating the energy transduction required for sheath contraction and effector delivery.

description: VFG043360(gb|WP_010948024) (motA) flagellar motor stator protein MotA [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the flagellar motor stator protein MotA from Legionella pneumophila, a critical virulence factor enabling this opportunistic pathogen's motility and host colonization. This transmembrane protein functions as the essential proton channel that energizes flagellar rotation by converting proton motive force into mechanical torque. Design the protein with four transmembrane helices forming the proton conduction pathway, with key conserved residues for proton translocation including essential aspartate and arginine residues in the cytoplasmic loop regions. Include the characteristic cytoplasmic domains that interact with the MotB partner protein to form the stable stator complex anchored to the peptidoglycan layer. The protein must maintain the proper topology with N- and C-terminal regions facing the cytoplasm, and incorporate the conserved motifs required for torque generation and regulation of stator assembly around the flagellar basal body. Ensure the sequence reflects adaptation to Legionella's aquatic and intracellular lifestyle, with appropriate hydrophobicity patterns for membrane integration and cytoplasmic domains optimized for protein-protein interactions within the flagellar motor complex.

description: VFG002024(gb|YP_002344526) (waaC) heptosyltransferase I [LOS (VF0326) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168]
prompt: Design a functional heptosyltransferase I enzyme from Campylobacter jejuni, a major human pathogen responsible for bacterial gastroenteritis worldwide. This enzyme, known as WaaC, is a critical virulence factor that functions in the biosynthesis of lipooligosaccharide (LOS), a key surface structure that mimics human gangliosides to evade host immune recognition. The protein should catalyze the transfer of the first heptose sugar from ADP-heptose to the inner core region of the LOS, specifically adding L-glycero-D-manno-heptose to the Kdo2-lipid A acceptor. This initial heptosylation step is essential for subsequent sugar additions and the complete assembly of the LOS outer core, which is crucial for immune modulation through molecular mimicry. The enzyme should contain the characteristic glycosyltransferase family 9 (GT9) domain with conserved catalytic residues for nucleotide sugar binding and transfer. It should adopt a typical GT-B fold structure with two distinct Rossmann-like domains separated by a deep active site cleft. The N-terminal domain should bind the ADP-heptose donor substrate, while the C-terminal domain should recognize the Kdo2-lipid A acceptor. Key structural features should include conserved motifs for metal ion coordination (likely Mg2+ or Mn2+), specific residues for sugar nucleotide recognition, and hydrophobic regions for membrane association since it functions at the cytoplasmic face of the inner membrane. The protein should exhibit optimal activity at physiological conditions relevant to the human gastrointestinal tract environment where Campylobacter establishes infection.

description: VFG045520(gb|WP_010947043) (legC1) Dot/Icm type IV secretion system effector LegC1 [Dot/Icm T4SS secreted effectors (VF0798) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for LegC1, a critical Dot/Icm Type IV secretion system effector protein from Legionella pneumophila. This protein functions as a key virulence factor that is translocated into host cells to subvert eukaryotic cellular processes and establish the Legionella-containing vacuole, enabling intracellular bacterial replication. LegC1 should contain conserved domains characteristic of bacterial effector proteins, including motifs for Dot/Icm recognition and translocation, as well as functional regions that interact with host cell components. The protein should exhibit structural features typical of secreted effectors, with appropriate signal sequences for Type IV secretion system recognition and domains that facilitate host-pathogen interactions. The sequence must reflect the protein's role in manipulating host cell signaling pathways and membrane trafficking processes to create a replication-permissive niche within human macrophages and other phagocytic cells.

description: VFG049684(gb|NP_220380) (CT_858) serine protease [CPAF (VF0580) - Exoenzyme (VFC0251)] [Chlamydia trachomatis D/UW-3/CX]
prompt: Design a serine protease virulence factor from Chlamydia trachomatis, specifically the CPAF (Chlamydial Protease/Proteasome-like Activity Factor) exoenzyme. This protein is a critical virulence determinant in Chlamydia pathogenesis, functioning as a secreted protease that cleaves host cell proteins to evade immune detection and facilitate intracellular survival. The protease should exhibit chymotrypsin-like serine protease activity with a catalytic triad typically consisting of histidine, aspartate, and serine residues. It likely functions as a homodimer with a bilobed structure characteristic of CPAF, where the N-terminal domain contains regulatory elements and the C-terminal domain houses the catalytic core. The protein should contain conserved domains for substrate recognition and proteolytic activity, including substrate-binding pockets that accommodate specific host protein targets. As an exoenzyme, it requires secretion signals for translocation from the bacterial cytosol into the host cell cytoplasm, where it targets key host proteins involved in antigen presentation, apoptosis, and inflammatory signaling pathways. The structural design should ensure proper folding into the characteristic protease conformation with appropriate active site geometry for efficient substrate cleavage while maintaining stability in the host cellular environment.

description: VFG033587(gb|WP_000723931) (escC) Type III secretion system secretin EscC [TTSS (VF0172) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Escherichia coli O127:H6 str. E2348/69]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the EscC protein, a critical component of the Type III Secretion System (T3SS) in Escherichia coli O127:H6 strain E2348/69. This protein functions as a secretin, forming a large, multimeric β-barrel pore complex in the outer membrane that facilitates the translocation of effector proteins and structural components of the T3SS injectisome. The sequence should include: (1) An N-terminal signal peptide for Sec-dependent transport to the periplasm, (2) A conserved secretin domain characteristic of the GspD family, featuring multiple β-strands that assemble into the transmembrane channel, (3) Specific motifs for interaction with the pilotin protein that guides proper localization and assembly, (4) Regions for oligomerization into the dodecameric ring structure, (5) Flexible loops that may serve as gating mechanisms for substrate passage, and (6) A C-terminal domain involved in complex stability and potential regulatory interactions. The protein must maintain structural integrity to withstand the mechanical stress of effector protein translocation while preventing nonspecific permeability of the outer membrane. Consider the evolutionary conservation of secretin domains across bacterial pathogens and the specific adaptations of E. coli O127:H6 for enteropathogenic virulence.

description: VFG000198(gb|NP_250394) (pcrD) type III secretion system protein PcrD [TTSS (VF0083) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Pseudomonas aeruginosa PAO1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the PcrD protein, a critical component of the Type III Secretion System (TTSS) in Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a Gram-negative opportunistic pathogen notorious for causing severe infections in immunocompromised individuals, cystic fibrosis patients, and hospital-acquired pneumonia. As a core structural protein of the TTSS, PcrD functions as an essential inner membrane ring component that forms part of the secretion apparatus base, facilitating the energy-dependent translocation of effector proteins directly into host cells. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of TTSS export apparatus components, including multiple transmembrane helices that anchor it to the inner bacterial membrane, cytoplasmic domains involved in protein-protein interactions with other TTSS components, and regions responsible for substrate recognition and energy coupling. The sequence should reflect the structural requirements for forming a stable oligomeric complex with other TTSS proteins such as PcrC and PcrR, maintaining the structural integrity of the secretion channel, and participating in the ATP-dependent export process. The protein must be localized to the inner bacterial membrane with both periplasmic and cytoplasmic exposed regions, enabling its role in bridging the inner membrane transport machinery with the periplasmic components of the needle complex. The generated sequence should ensure proper hydrophobic character for membrane integration while maintaining soluble domains with appropriate charge distribution for interaction with both cytoplasmic ATPases and periplasmic partners in the complete virulence apparatus.

description: VFG042793(gb|WP_012477167) (bfpH) lipoprotein [BFP (VF0174) - Adherence (VFC0001)] [Escherichia coli O127:H6 str. E2348/69]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the BfpB lipoprotein, a critical structural component of the Bundle-Forming Pilus (BFP) in enteropathogenic Escherichia coli O127:H6 strain E2348/69. This protein functions as a major virulence factor essential for bacterial adherence to intestinal epithelial cells, facilitating the initial colonization phase of infection. BfpB is an outer membrane lipoprotein that serves as the platform for BFP biogenesis, anchoring the pilus structure to the bacterial cell envelope. The protein contains characteristic lipoprotein features including an N-terminal signal peptide with a lipobox motif for lipid modification and outer membrane localization. It possesses multiple transmembrane domains that facilitate its integration into the outer membrane while maintaining extracellular domains for pilus subunit interactions. The mature protein should exhibit conserved domains typical of pilus assembly platforms, including regions for protein-protein interactions with other BFP components such as BfpA (the major pilin subunit) and the usher/chaperone machinery. The sequence should reflect structural characteristics that enable its role in stabilizing the pilus base and mediating host cell attachment through direct or indirect interactions with epithelial surface receptors. The protein's architecture must support its function as a molecular scaffold that coordinates the assembly and extension of the adhesive pilus fibers critical for establishing microcolonies and initiating the attaching and effacing lesions characteristic of enteropathogenic E. coli infections.

description: VFG041258(gb|WP_010946433) (lem3) Dot/Icm type IV secretion system effector Lem3, Dephosphoryl-cholinase relieving the AnkX-mediated modification on Rab1 [Dot/Icm T4SS secreted effectors (VF0798) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for Lem3, a specialized Dot/Icm type IV secretion system effector protein from the bacterial pathogen Legionella pneumophila. This protein functions as a dephosphoryl-cholinase enzyme that specifically counteracts the AnkX-mediated phosphocholination modification on the host GTPase Rab1. Legionella pneumophila is a significant human pathogen responsible for Legionnaires' disease, and it employs the Dot/Icm type IV secretion system as its primary virulence mechanism to deliver effector proteins directly into host cells, enabling intracellular replication within a specialized Legionella-containing vacuole. Lem3 plays a crucial regulatory role in the temporal control of Rab1 manipulation during infection by reversing the phosphocholination modification installed by the AnkX effector, thereby fine-tuning Rab1 activity and membrane trafficking dynamics. The protein should contain conserved catalytic domains characteristic of dephosphoryl-cholinase enzymes, likely featuring a hydrolase fold with specific active site residues capable of cleaving the phosphocholine moiety from modified Rab1. As a T4SS substrate, Lem3 must include appropriate secretion signals and structural features compatible with translocation through the Dot/Icm apparatus. The protein should exhibit characteristics typical of bacterial effector proteins, including appropriate molecular weight, potential interaction surfaces for host protein recognition, and structural stability for intracellular function. The sequence should reflect the evolutionary optimization for host-pathogen interaction while maintaining functional specificity for Rab1 dephosphocholination.

description: VFG000827(gb|WP_001299599) (escR) Type III secretion systemminor export apparatus protein EscR [TTSS (VF0191) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Escherichia coli O157:H7 str. EDL933]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for EscR, a critical component of the Type III Secretion System (T3SS) export apparatus in Escherichia coli O157:H7. This enteropathogenic E. coli strain is a significant human pathogen causing severe gastrointestinal diseases, including hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic-uremic syndrome. EscR functions as a minor export apparatus protein that forms part of the transmembrane complex responsible for recognizing and translocating effector proteins across the bacterial inner membrane. The protein should contain multiple transmembrane domains characteristic of inner membrane localization, with conserved hydrophobic regions that facilitate integration into the lipid bilayer. Include conserved residues involved in protein-protein interactions with other export apparatus components (EscS, EscT, EscU) to form the functional complex. The sequence should feature specific motifs for ATP binding and hydrolysis coordination, though EscR itself may not directly hydrolyze ATP but rather facilitates the process through interactions with the ATPase complex. Incorporate structural elements that allow for conformational changes during the substrate recognition and translocation process, including flexible linker regions between transmembrane segments. The protein should maintain the characteristic topology of T3SS export apparatus proteins with cytoplasmic, transmembrane, and periplasmic domains arranged to create the export channel. Ensure the sequence includes conserved charged residues in cytoplasmic regions that participate in effector protein recognition and sorting. The overall architecture should support the protein's role in maintaining the integrity of the export apparatus while facilitating the selective transport of virulence effectors into host cells during infection.

description: VFG038884(gb|WP_005314225) (lafC) LafC, flagellar export chaperone [Lateral flagella (VF0474) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida A449]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for LafC, a flagellar export chaperone protein from Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida. This protein functions as a specialized chaperone within the lateral flagellar system of this significant fish pathogen, which causes furunculosis in salmonid species. LafC plays a critical role in the type III secretion-dependent assembly of lateral flagella, which are essential for bacterial motility in viscous environments and host tissue colonization. The protein should exhibit characteristic features of flagellar export chaperones, including a compact alpha-helical bundle structure that facilitates specific binding to flagellar substrate proteins. It should contain conserved chaperone domains that prevent premature aggregation of flagellar components in the cytoplasm and mediate their targeted delivery to the flagellar type III secretion apparatus. The sequence should include motifs for ATP-independent substrate recognition and binding, typically involving hydrophobic patches and charged residues that interact with N-terminal regions of flagellar export substrates. LafC likely functions as part of a chaperone hierarchy that ensures the ordered assembly of lateral flagellar structures, with specific affinity for components of the flagellar hook-basal body complex or export apparatus. The protein should be cytoplasmic in localization and exhibit the characteristic size and physicochemical properties of class II flagellar chaperones, with appropriate surface properties for transient protein-protein interactions while maintaining solubility. The generated sequence must enable proper folding into a stable chaperone structure capable of recognizing and escorting specific flagellar substrates to the export gate while preventing their degradation or misfolding.

description: VFG001988(gb|YP_002344798) (cysC) adenylyl-sulfate kinase [Capsule (VF0323) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168]
prompt: Design a functional adenylyl-sulfate kinase enzyme from Campylobacter jejuni subsp. jejuni NCTC 11168, a major human gastrointestinal pathogen responsible for bacterial enteritis. This protein, encoded by the cysC gene, plays a critical role in the sulfate assimilation pathway by catalyzing the ATP-dependent phosphorylation of adenosine 5'-phosphosulfate (APS) to form 3'-phosphoadenosine-5'-phosphosulfate (PAPS), the universal sulfuryl group donor for cellular sulfation reactions. As a virulence factor, this enzyme contributes to capsule biosynthesis and immune modulation by enabling the sulfation of capsular polysaccharides and other surface structures that facilitate host immune evasion and colonization. The protein should contain conserved kinase domains typical of the ASK superfamily, including a nucleotide-binding P-loop motif (GXXGXGK) for ATP coordination, a catalytic loop for phosphoryl transfer, and substrate-binding pockets that specifically recognize APS while excluding other nucleotides. The structure should adopt the characteristic bilobal kinase fold with an N-terminal ATP-grasp domain and a C-terminal substrate-binding domain connected by a flexible hinge region. Key catalytic residues should be positioned to facilitate magnesium-dependent phosphoryl transfer from ATP to the 3'-OH of APS. The enzyme should exhibit optimal activity under microaerobic conditions reflective of the Campylobacter jejuni intestinal niche and maintain structural stability in the bacterial cytoplasm where it interfaces with other sulfate assimilation enzymes like sulfate adenyltransferase (CysD/CysN) and phosphoadenosine phosphosulfate reductase (CysH).

description: VFG000823(gb|WP_000720639) (etgA) T3SS-associated peptidoglycan lytic enzyme  [TTSS (VF0191) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Escherichia coli O157:H7 str. EDL933]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for EtgA, a Type III Secretion System (T3SS)-associated peptidoglycan lytic enzyme from Escherichia coli O157:H7. This virulence factor is a critical component of the T3SS effector delivery system in this enteropathogenic E. coli strain, which causes severe foodborne illness and hemorrhagic colitis. EtgA functions as a specialized peptidoglycan-degrading enzyme that facilitates T3SS apparatus assembly and effector protein translocation by locally remodeling the bacterial cell wall. The enzyme likely contains conserved catalytic domains characteristic of peptidoglycan lytic transglycosylases, including a glycosyl hydrolase domain with muramidase activity that cleaves the β-1,4-glycosidic bonds between N-acetylmuramic acid and N-acetylglucosamine residues in peptidoglycan. Structural analysis suggests the protein adopts a modular architecture with a catalytic domain featuring the characteristic active site glutamate residue essential for proton donation during glycosidic bond cleavage, potentially accompanied by accessory domains that mediate interaction with the T3SS basal body components. The enzyme operates at the bacterial inner membrane-T3SS interface, where it creates localized openings in the peptidoglycan layer to accommodate the assembly of the T3SS needle complex, thereby enabling the secretion of virulence effectors into host cells. The sequence should reflect optimal catalytic efficiency for peptidoglycan degradation while maintaining structural compatibility with the T3SS machinery and membrane association properties.

description: VFG000826(gb|WP_000379425) (escS) Type III secretion systemminor export apparatus protein EscS [TTSS (VF0191) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Escherichia coli O157:H7 str. EDL933]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for EscS, a critical minor export apparatus protein from the Type III Secretion System (T3SS) of Escherichia coli O157:H7. The protein should exhibit conserved structural features typical of T3SS export apparatus components, including potential coiled-coil regions for protein-protein interactions and nucleotide-binding domains that may coordinate with the ATPase complex for energy-dependent substrate translocation. EscS plays a crucial role in recognizing and facilitating the export of T3SS substrates through the needle complex, distinguishing between early (structural) and late (effector) substrates. description: VFG001360(gb|WP_001042179) (nanB) neuraminidase B [Neuraminidase (VF0148) - Exoenzyme (VFC0251)] [Streptococcus pneumoniae TIGR4]
prompt: Design a functional neuraminidase B protein from Streptococcus pneumoniae strain TIGR4, a major human respiratory pathogen responsible for pneumonia, meningitis, and sepsis. This virulence factor is an exoenzyme that cleaves terminal sialic acid residues from host glycoproteins and glycolipids, facilitating bacterial colonization, immune evasion, and nutrient acquisition. The protein should contain conserved neuraminidase domains characteristic of the glycosyl hydrolase family, including the canonical Asp-box motifs and catalytic residues essential for sialidase activity. Structure should feature the characteristic beta-propeller fold with multiple blade domains that form the active site pocket. Include signal peptide sequences for extracellular secretion and surface localization. The enzyme should demonstrate optimal activity at physiological temperatures and pH ranges encountered in human respiratory tissues, with substrate specificity for alpha-2,3 and alpha-2,6 linked sialic acids commonly found on human epithelial cell surfaces. The protein should facilitate bacterial adherence to respiratory epithelium, complement resistance through cleavage of sialic acid-containing complement regulators, and exposure of host cell receptors for enhanced invasion.

description: VFG038885(gb|WP_005314224) (lafX) LafX [Lateral flagella (VF0474) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida A449]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for LafX, a critical virulence factor from the fish pathogen Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida. LafX should contain conserved domains characteristic of flagellar structural proteins, likely including helical regions for filament assembly and interaction domains for integration into the flagellar basal body-hook-filament complex. The protein should exhibit appropriate hydrophobicity patterns for membrane association and contain motifs for protein-protein interactions within the flagellar apparatus. Structure should include regions for proper folding into the flagellar architecture, with consideration for the rotational mechanics of lateral flagella. The sequence must enable proper assembly into the functional motility apparatus that allows A. salmonicida to navigate host tissues and establish infection.

description: VFG000543(gb|NP_461803) (sipA/sspA) type III secretion system effector SipA (Salmonella invasion protein A) [TTSS-1 secreted effectors (VF0949) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2]

Structurally, SipA should adopt an elongated conformation with flexible regions that allow it to bridge actin filaments while maintaining stability during translocation. The sequence must enable the protein to bind F-actin with high affinity, prevent actin depolymerization, and promote membrane ruffling and bacterial internalization. The protein should be optimized for efficient secretion through the needle complex and rapid deployment upon host cell contact, featuring appropriate surface properties for host-pathogen interface interactions while maintaining structural integrity during the acidic and proteolytic conditions encountered during infection.

description: VFG042788(gb|WP_000464849) (bfpU) periplasmic protein [BFP (VF0174) - Adherence (VFC0001)] [Escherichia coli O127:H6 str. E2348/69]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for BfpU, a periplasmic component of the Bundle-Forming Pilus (BFP) system in the enteropathogenic Escherichia coli O127:H6 strain E2348/69. This protein functions as a critical virulence factor in bacterial adherence to intestinal epithelial cells, facilitating the initial attachment phase of infection. BfpU is localized to the bacterial periplasm where it participates in the biogenesis and assembly of the type IV bundle-forming pili. The protein likely contains conserved domains characteristic of pilus assembly machinery, including potential chaperone-binding regions and interaction domains for other BFP components such as the major pilin subunit BfpA. The sequence should reflect the functional requirements for proper pilus polymerization, including conserved residues for interaction with the usher protein BfpC and other assembly components. The protein must maintain structural integrity in the periplasmic environment while enabling efficient pilus biogenesis and bacterial adhesion to host cells.

description: VFG000538(gb|NP_461797) (hilA) transcriptional regulator [TTSS (SPI-1 encode) (VF0116) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for HilA, a key transcriptional regulator from Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium. HilA functions as the master regulator of the Salmonella Pathogenicity Island 1 (SPI-1)-encoded Type III Secretion System (TTSS), which is essential for bacterial invasion of host intestinal epithelial cells. As a member of the OmpR/ToxR family of response regulators, HilA should contain a conserved N-terminal receiver domain with a phosphorylation site (typically aspartate residue) for signal transduction from upstream sensors like BarA/SirA, and a C-terminal winged-helix DNA-binding domain that recognizes specific promoter sequences of SPI-1 genes. The protein should exhibit a modular structure that allows phosphorylation-dependent activation, leading to dimerization and enhanced DNA binding affinity. HilA directly activates transcription of invasion genes including the TTSS structural components (Prg/Org/Inv/Spa operons) and effector proteins (Sip/Sop proteins), coordinating the assembly of the needle complex and effector delivery apparatus. The sequence should reflect its cytoplasmic localization and role in integrating environmental signals (osmolarity, oxygen tension, pH) to trigger the invasive phenotype during early infection stages.

description: VFG002019(gb|WP_013101527) (fliM) flagellar motor switch protein FliM [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Design a flagellar motor switch protein FliM from Legionella pneumophila, a critical virulence factor enabling this opportunistic pathogen's motility and environmental persistence. This protein functions as an essential component of the flagellar basal body's C-ring structure, where it mediates directional switching between clockwise and counterclockwise flagellar rotation in response to chemotactic signals. The protein should contain multiple FliM domains arranged to form the switch complex interface, with conserved residues for binding the response regulator CheY-P and interacting with other switch proteins FliG and FliN. Structure should feature characteristic α-helical bundles and β-sheets forming the compact, globular domains typical of bacterial switch complexes. Include the conserved GXXXS motif involved in CheY binding and the hydrophobic patches essential for proper assembly within the C-ring. The protein must maintain the appropriate molecular weight and pI for integration into the flagellar motor apparatus, with surface properties enabling dynamic conformational changes during rotational switching while maintaining structural stability within the bacterial cytoplasm.

description: VFG045296(gb|WP_164919819) (LPG_RS03710) N-acetyl sugar amidotransferase [LPS (VF0171) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Design a functional N-acetyl sugar amidotransferase enzyme from Legionella pneumophila, the causative agent of Legionnaires' disease. This virulence factor plays a critical role in modifying the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) layer of the bacterial outer membrane, specifically contributing to immune modulation by altering surface antigenicity and enhancing bacterial evasion of host immune recognition. The enzyme should catalyze the transfer of amino groups to N-acetyl sugar substrates, a key step in the biosynthesis of complex LPS structures that mimic host glycans to subvert immune detection. Incorporate conserved domains typical of sugar amidotransferases, including a catalytic domain with residues for substrate binding and amide transfer, and potential oligomerization interfaces for functional complex formation. Structure should feature alpha/beta folds with active site pockets accommodating N-acetyl hexosamine substrates, and surface characteristics compatible with integration into the cytoplasmic membrane or periplasmic space for LPS modification. Ensure the sequence reflects Legionella-specific adaptations for intracellular survival and immune evasion, with appropriate signal peptides if required for localization to the bacterial envelope where LPS assembly occurs.

description: VFG050901(gb|WP_005119983.1) (cpaA) metalloendopeptidase CpaA [CpaA (VF1336) - Exoenzyme (VFC0251)] [Acinetobacter baumannii BJAB0715]

The protein should contain characteristic metallopeptidase domains, including the conserved HEXXH zinc-binding motif essential for catalytic activity, and likely features additional domains for substrate recognition and binding. Structurally, it should adopt a globular fold typical of metalloendopeptidases, with the active site positioned to accommodate diverse protein substrates. As an exoenzyme, it must include an N-terminal secretion signal peptide for export via the bacterial secretion system, and the mature protein should exhibit optimal stability and activity in the extracellular environment. description: VFG039156(gb|NP_820614) (icmO/dotL) Type IVB secretion system protein IcmO/DotL,an inner membrane ATPase of the type IV coupling protein complex  [Dot/Icm T4SS (VF0503) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Coxiella burnetii RSA 493]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for IcmO/DotL, a critical inner membrane ATPase component of the Type IVB secretion system (T4BSS) from Coxiella burnetii. This intracellular bacterial pathogen causes Q fever and employs the Dot/Icm T4BSS as its primary virulence mechanism to translocate effector proteins into host cells, enabling establishment of the unique Coxiella-containing vacuole for intracellular replication. IcmO/DotL functions as the central ATPase motor within the Type IV coupling protein (T4CP) complex, providing the mechanical energy required for substrate recognition, unfolding, and translocation through the secretion channel. The protein should contain conserved Walker A and Walker B motifs characteristic of AAA+ ATPases, along with additional nucleotide-binding domains that facilitate ATP hydrolysis. Structural analysis indicates this inner membrane protein likely features multiple transmembrane helices for membrane integration, a large cytoplasmic domain housing the ATPase machinery, and specific interaction interfaces for coupling with both the inner membrane transport apparatus and effector protein substrates. The sequence must reflect the characteristic features of T4CP ATPases, including regions for oligomerization into hexameric rings, conserved catalytic residues for ATP binding and hydrolysis, and domains that coordinate with other T4SS components like the core complex and pilus apparatus. The generated protein should be functionally competent to drive the ATP-dependent transport of virulence effectors across the bacterial inner membrane during host cell infection.

description: VFG043362(gb|WP_011947507) (LPG_RS13035) flagellar protein [Flagella (VF0157) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Legionella pneumophila subsp. pneumophila str. Philadelphia 1]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for a flagellar protein from Legionella pneumophila, a Gram-negative bacterial pathogen responsible for Legionnaires' disease. This protein is an essential structural component of the flagellar apparatus, which mediates bacterial motility critical for host colonization, biofilm formation, and environmental persistence. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of flagellar structural proteins, including helical regions for filament assembly and interaction motifs for integration into the flagellar basal body-hook-filament complex. It should feature amphipathic sequences enabling membrane association and oligomerization, with appropriate hydrophobic regions for insertion into the bacterial membrane or interaction with other flagellar components. The structure should facilitate torque transmission from the motor to the filament, contributing to the whip-like propulsion mechanism. Include conserved residues for protein-protein interactions within the multi-subunit flagellar complex and maintain the overall architecture required for mechanical stability during rotation. The sequence should reflect the characteristic length and charge distribution of bacterial flagellar proteins, with appropriate signal sequences or export signals if required for flagellar assembly through the type III secretion-like flagellar export apparatus.

description: VFG002551(gb|WP_004522170) (wcbO) capsule polysaccharide biosynthesis/export protein [Capsule I (VF0436) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Burkholderia pseudomallei K96243]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for WcbO, a critical capsule polysaccharide biosynthesis and export protein from the highly virulent bacterial pathogen Burkholderia pseudomallei. This protein functions as an essential component of the capsule biosynthesis machinery, specifically involved in the assembly and export of the capsular polysaccharide that constitutes the major virulence determinant Capsule I. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of polysaccharide biosynthesis enzymes, likely including glycosyltransferase domains for sugar nucleotide transfer, transmembrane domains for membrane association within the biosynthesis complex, and export signal sequences for directing the synthesized polysaccharide to the cell surface. The structural architecture should facilitate interaction with other capsule biosynthesis proteins to form a functional complex that polymerizes and exports the capsular material. This capsule provides critical immune evasion capabilities by resisting phagocytosis, complement-mediated killing, and opsonization, thereby enabling systemic dissemination and persistence of the bacterium in mammalian hosts. The protein sequence must reflect its role in maintaining the structural integrity of the capsule biosynthesis pathway and its contribution to the exceptional virulence of this Category B select agent.

description: VFG000982(gb|WP_010922229) (speH) streptococcal exotoxin H precursor [Spes (VF0248) - Exotoxin (VFC0235)] [Streptococcus pyogenes M1 GAS]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for streptococcal exotoxin H (SpeH), a critical virulence factor from Streptococcus pyogenes M1 GAS. This protein functions as a potent exotoxin that contributes to the pathogenesis of group A streptococcal infections, including streptococcal toxic shock syndrome and necrotizing fasciitis. SpeH belongs to the superantigen family of exotoxins and operates by cross-linking major histocompatibility complex class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells with T-cell receptors, leading to massive polyclonal T-cell activation and cytokine storm. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins, including a conserved N-terminal domain involved in MHC II binding and a C-terminal domain responsible for T-cell receptor interaction. Key structural features should include: (1) a signal peptide for secretion, (2) the characteristic β-grasp fold common to superantigens, (3) multiple β-strands forming the core structure, (4) conserved hydrophobic regions for receptor binding, and (5) specific amino acid residues critical for zinc coordination if applicable. The mature protein should be extracellularly localized and exhibit thermal stability typical of bacterial superantigens. Ensure the sequence reflects the characteristic isoelectric point and molecular weight range for streptococcal exotoxins, with appropriate distribution of charged residues for receptor interaction and immune system evasion.

description: VFG048972(gb|WP_014907221) (KP1_RS17340) polysaccharide export protein [Capsule (VF0560) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Klebsiella pneumoniae subsp. pneumoniae NTUH-K2044]
