This protein functions as a critical virulence factor responsible for the export and assembly of capsular polysaccharide, which forms a protective capsule around the bacterial cell. The capsule serves as a primary immune evasion mechanism by inhibiting phagocytosis, complement-mediated killing, and antimicrobial peptide activity, thereby enabling systemic dissemination and persistence in the host. The protein should contain conserved domains typical of polysaccharide export machinery, including transmembrane domains for membrane integration, nucleotide-binding domains for energy coupling, and specific recognition motifs for polysaccharide substrate binding and translocation. Structurally, it should form part of an ATP-binding cassette (ABC) transporter complex that spans the inner membrane, utilizing ATP hydrolysis to drive the unidirectional export of capsular polysaccharide precursors from the cytoplasm to the periplasmic space for subsequent polymerization and surface attachment. The protein should exhibit characteristic features of bacterial export proteins, including appropriate signal sequences for membrane targeting, conserved Walker A and Walker B motifs for ATP binding and hydrolysis, and specific interaction domains for coordinating with other components of the capsule biosynthesis machinery. The overall architecture should facilitate efficient polysaccharide transport while maintaining structural integrity within the bacterial envelope.

description: VFG007020(gb|WP_001881196) (rtxC) RTX toxin activating protein RtxC [MARTX (VF0265) - Exotoxin (VFC0235)] [Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar El Tor str. N16961]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for RtxC, the RTX toxin activating protein from Vibrio cholerae O1 biovar El Tor. This protein is a critical component of the MARTX (Multifunctional Autoprocessing RTX) toxin system, functioning as the acyltransferase enzyme responsible for activating the RTX toxin domain through post-translational modification. RtxC catalyzes the covalent linkage of fatty acyl groups to conserved lysine residues within the RTX repeats of the toxin, a modification essential for pore-forming activity and membrane insertion. The protein should contain characteristic acyltransferase domains with conserved catalytic residues, likely featuring a Rossmann-fold structure for nucleotide cofactor binding. As part of the MARTX toxin complex, RtxC operates in the bacterial cytoplasm where it modifies the nascent toxin polypeptide before secretion via the type I secretion system. The sequence should reflect the Gram-negative bacterial origin with appropriate codon usage bias and lack eukaryotic post-translational modification signals. Include conserved motifs for acyltransferase activity and any domains required for interaction with other MARTX components, ensuring the generated sequence maintains the structural integrity necessary for enzymatic function in toxin activation within the cholera virulence pathway.

description: VFG039161(gb|NP_820615) (icmP/dotM) Type IVB secretion system protein IcmP/DotM, inner membrane/cytoplasmic protein of the type IV coupling protein complex  [Dot/Icm T4SS (VF0503) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Coxiella burnetii RSA 493]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for the IcmP/DotM protein, a critical component of the Dot/Icm Type IVB secretion system (T4BSS) in Coxiella burnetii. This obligate intracellular bacterial pathogen is the causative agent of Q fever and relies on the Dot/Icm system to translocate effector proteins into host cells, enabling intracellular survival and replication. IcmP/DotM functions as an inner membrane/cytoplasmic protein within the type IV coupling protein (T4CP) complex, which serves as the central hub for substrate recognition and energy transduction. The protein likely contains multiple transmembrane domains that anchor it to the inner membrane, with cytoplasmic regions facilitating interactions with other T4CP components (e.g., DotL, DotN) and effector proteins. Key structural features include conserved ATP-binding motifs (e.g., Walker A/B motifs) if it participates in ATP hydrolysis, coiled-coil domains for protein-protein interactions, and flexible linker regions that allow conformational changes during substrate loading. The mechanism involves coupling cytoplasmic effector recognition to the secretion apparatus, potentially through direct binding to effector proteins or adaptors, and coordinating with the DotO ATPase for energizing substrate transfer. The sequence should reflect a modular architecture with N-terminal transmembrane helices, central soluble domains for complex assembly, and C-terminal regions involved in effector binding or regulatory functions, ensuring compatibility with the Gram-negative bacterial inner membrane and the T4BSS machinery.

description: VFG002547(gb|WP_004527661) (wcbS) UDP-3-O-[3-hydroxymyristoyl] N-acetylglucosamine deacetylase [Capsule I (VF0436) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Burkholderia pseudomallei K96243]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the UDP-3-O-[3-hydroxymyristoyl] N-acetylglucosamine deacetylase enzyme, designated as WcbS, from the highly virulent bacterial pathogen Burkholderia pseudomallei. This enzyme serves as a critical virulence factor by catalyzing the deacetylation step in the biosynthesis of the capsular polysaccharide, a major determinant of immune evasion and persistence during melioidosis infection. The protein functions within the Capsule I biosynthesis pathway, specifically modifying the lipid-linked precursor by removing the acetyl group from UDP-3-O-[3-hydroxymyristoyl] N-acetylglucosamine, thereby enabling subsequent glycosyl transfer reactions essential for capsule assembly. WcbS is predicted to be an integral membrane protein or membrane-associated enzyme, featuring conserved deacetylase domains with characteristic catalytic residues (likely including zinc-binding motifs and conserved histidine/aspartate pairs) that facilitate amide bond hydrolysis. The enzyme's active site accommodates the lipid-modified UDP-sugar substrate, with structural elements that recognize both the UDP moiety and the 3-hydroxymyristoyl chain, ensuring substrate specificity. The generated sequence should reflect appropriate transmembrane regions or membrane-anchoring domains, maintain the precise spatial arrangement of catalytic residues for efficient deacetylation, and include any necessary cofactor-binding sites. The overall architecture should support the enzyme's role in the coordinated multi-enzyme complex responsible for capsule production, a key virulence mechanism that protects the bacterium from host phagocytosis and complement-mediated killing.

description: VFG048996(gb|WP_004213609) (rmpA) regulator of mucoid phenotype RmpA [RmpA (VF0570) - Regulation (VFC0301)] [Klebsiella pneumoniae subsp. pneumoniae NTUH-K2044]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the RmpA protein, a key transcriptional regulator of mucoid phenotype in Klebsiella pneumoniae. This protein functions as a central virulence determinant by activating the expression of capsular polysaccharide biosynthesis genes, leading to hypermucoviscosity - a hallmark trait of hypervirulent K. pneumoniae strains. RmpA belongs to the MarR family of transcriptional regulators and likely contains a conserved DNA-binding winged helix-turn-helix domain that enables sequence-specific recognition of promoter regions controlling capsule gene clusters. The protein should exhibit characteristic features of bacterial transcriptional regulators, including distinct DNA-binding and potential ligand-binding domains, with structural elements that facilitate dimerization for cooperative DNA binding. The sequence must encode a protein capable of binding to specific regulatory sequences upstream of capsule biosynthesis operons, thereby enhancing polysaccharide production and contributing to the organism's ability to evade host immune clearance through increased resistance to phagocytosis and serum killing. The generated sequence should reflect the functional requirements for interacting with RNA polymerase and modulating transcription initiation while maintaining the structural integrity necessary for its regulatory role in this clinically significant pathogen's virulence mechanism.

description: VFG032845(gb|NP_466072) (gtcA) wall teichoic acid glycosylation protein GtcA [GtcA (VF0607) - Post-translational modification (VFC0315)] [Listeria monocytogenes EGD-e]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for GtcA, a wall teichoic acid glycosylation enzyme from the Gram-positive bacterial pathogen Listeria monocytogenes. This protein functions as a critical virulence factor by mediating the glycosylation of wall teichoic acids (WTAs), which are essential cell wall polymers. GtcA catalyzes the transfer of sugar moieties, likely glucose or galactose, from nucleotide sugar donors to the ribitol phosphate backbone of WTAs. This glycosylation modification is crucial for bacterial virulence as it enables immune evasion by masking pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) from host innate immune recognition, particularly by reducing detection by Toll-like receptor 2 (TLR2). The protein should contain conserved glycosyltransferase domains, typically including a GT-A or GT-B fold with characteristic nucleotide-binding motifs for coordinating sugar donors. It likely functions as a membrane-associated or integral membrane protein, given its role in modifying cell wall components, and may contain transmembrane helices or membrane-anchoring regions. The enzyme should exhibit specificity for wall teichoic acid substrates and demonstrate the characteristic catalytic residues for glycosyl transfer, including aspartate or glutamate residues that act as catalytic bases. The structural organization should support the proper orientation for substrate binding and catalysis at the membrane-cell wall interface.

description: VFG000980(gb|WP_010921949) (speJ) streptococcal exotoxin J precursor [Spes (VF0248) - Exotoxin (VFC0235)] [Streptococcus pyogenes M1 GAS]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for streptococcal exotoxin J (SpeJ), a key virulence factor from Streptococcus pyogenes M1 GAS. This protein functions as a potent exotoxin that contributes to the pathogenesis of group A streptococcal infections, including streptococcal toxic shock syndrome and necrotizing fasciitis. As a member of the streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin family, it likely exhibits superantigen activity, bypassing conventional antigen presentation to trigger massive, non-specific T-cell activation and cytokine release. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of bacterial superantigens, including a stable β-sheet-rich core structure with α-helical regions that facilitate MHC class II and T-cell receptor binding. Key functional motifs should include residues for zinc coordination, which is critical for superantigen function, and regions involved in dimerization or oligomerization. The protein should be secreted as a precursor with a signal peptide for extracellular targeting, and the mature form should exhibit thermal stability and resistance to proteolytic degradation. Structural features should include the characteristic two-domain architecture of streptococcal superantigens, with one domain primarily engaging the T-cell receptor and the other interacting with MHC class II molecules. The protein should be optimized for high-affinity binding to both human immune receptors while maintaining the conformational stability required for its potent immunomodulatory effects in the host.

description: VFG013321(gb|WP_005693139) (lpxH) UDP-2,3-diacylglucosamine pyrophosphohydrolase [LOS (VF0044) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Haemophilus influenzae Rd KW20]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for UDP-2,3-diacylglucosamine pyrophosphohydrolase (LpxH) from Haemophilus influenzae strain Rd KW20, a critical enzyme in the lipooligosaccharide (LOS) biosynthesis pathway. This Gram-negative bacterial pathogen utilizes LOS as a major virulence factor for immune modulation and host colonization. LpxH functions as a membrane-associated hydrolase that catalyzes the fourth committed step in lipid A biosynthesis, specifically cleaving the pyrophosphate bond of UDP-2,3-diacylglucosamine to produce 2,3-diacylglucosamine-1-phosphate and UMP. The enzyme should contain conserved metallophosphoesterase domains characteristic of the LpxH family, with key catalytic residues for metal ion coordination and substrate binding. Structural features should include a compact α/β hydrolase fold with a deep active site pocket accommodating the UDP-diacylglucosamine substrate. The protein should exhibit membrane association through amphipathic helices or peripheral membrane interactions, positioning it optimally within the inner membrane for access to lipid intermediates. Conserved motifs should include the metal-binding histidine and aspartate residues essential for catalytic activity, as well as substrate recognition elements for both the UDP moiety and the diacylglucosamine portion. The generated sequence must maintain the precise enzymatic activity required for proper lipid A assembly, as this step is essential for constructing the membrane anchor of LOS, which mediates immune evasion through TLR4 modulation and contributes to serum resistance in this important human respiratory pathogen.

description: VFG000986(gb|NP_858260) (ipaC) type III secretion system hydrophilic translocator, pore protein IpaC [TTSS (VF0118) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Shigella flexneri 2a str. 301]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for IpaC, a hydrophilic translocator and pore-forming protein from Shigella flexneri serotype 2a strain 301. This protein is a critical component of the Type III Secretion System (T3SS), specifically functioning as part of the translocon complex that forms pores in host cell membranes to facilitate effector protein delivery. IpaC operates in conjunction with IpaB to create a hydrophobic-lipophilic balance at the host membrane interface, enabling the translocation of virulence effectors like IpaA, IpgD, and VirA into host epithelial cells. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of T3SS translocators, including membrane-interacting regions with amphipathic helices for pore formation, hydrophilic domains that interact with the T3SS needle tip, and flexible regions that undergo conformational changes upon host cell contact. Structurally, IpaC is expected to form an oligomeric beta-barrel-like pore structure in the host membrane, with N-terminal domains involved in needle complex interactions and C-terminal regions mediating membrane insertion and effector passage. The sequence should reflect its role in triggering actin cytoskeleton rearrangements and bacterial invasion, with specific motifs for secretion signal recognition by the T3SS apparatus, chaperone binding sites (e.g., for IpgC), and host membrane lipid interaction domains. Ensure the design captures the protein's dual role in pore formation and signaling initiation during Shigella pathogenesis.

description: VFG002162(gb|NP_465591) (bsh) bile salt hydrolase [BSH (VF0350) - Stress survival (VFC0282)] [Listeria monocytogenes EGD-e]
prompt: Design a functional bile salt hydrolase (BSH) protein from the foodborne pathogen Listeria monocytogenes. This enzyme is a critical virulence factor that enables bacterial survival in the hostile environment of the mammalian gastrointestinal tract. The protein must efficiently catalyze the hydrolysis of conjugated bile salts, specifically cleaving the amide bond between the steroid nucleus and amino acid side chains (glycine or taurine). This detoxification mechanism neutralizes the antimicrobial properties of bile salts, allowing Listeria to withstand intestinal stress and establish infection. The enzyme should feature the conserved catalytic triad typical of cysteine-dependent N-terminal nucleophile (Ntn) hydrolases, with a nucleophilic cysteine residue at the active site that initiates the hydrolytic reaction through a covalent acyl-enzyme intermediate. Include the characteristic αββα sandwich fold common to Ntn-hydrolases, with the active site situated in a deep pocket that accommodates the amphipathic bile salt substrates. The protein should be optimized for function in the bacterial cytoplasm, with appropriate surface properties for intracellular localization. Ensure the inclusion of conserved structural elements that maintain the proper geometry for substrate binding and catalysis, including residues involved in oxyanion hole formation and substrate recognition pockets that distinguish between different conjugated bile salts. The overall architecture should support the enzyme's role in Listeria's stress survival strategy during host colonization.

description: VFG000389(gb|WP_002212958) (lcrE/yopN) type III secretion system gatekeeper YopN [TTSS (VF0140) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Yersinia pestis CO92]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for the YopN protein, a critical type III secretion system (T3SS) gatekeeper from the highly virulent pathogen Yersinia pestis. This protein functions as a molecular switch that regulates effector protein translocation during bubonic and pneumonic plague pathogenesis. YopN operates at the interface between the bacterial cytoplasm and the T3SS needle complex, forming a plug-like structure that physically blocks the secretion channel in the absence of host cell contact. Upon calcium depletion in the host environment—a key signal of intracellular localization—YopN undergoes conformational changes that disengage from the secretion apparatus, permitting the ordered export of cytotoxic Yop effectors like YopE, YopH, and YopT into target eukaryotic cells. The protein should contain several conserved domains: an N-terminal cytoplasmic domain involved in regulatory interactions with TyeA and SycN chaperones, a central transmembrane region that anchors it to the inner membrane, and a C-terminal extracellular domain that participates in needle complex assembly and secretion control. Key functional motifs should include calcium-responsive helices, coiled-coil regions for oligomerization into a tetrameric complex, and specific binding interfaces for regulatory components. The structure should reflect a modular architecture capable of allosteric regulation, with predicted alpha-helical bundles and beta-strand regions that confer stability in the hostile environment of phagocytic vesicles. This gatekeeper mechanism is essential for preventing premature effector secretion, thereby optimizing bacterial survival and virulence during infection.

description: VFG000040(gb|WP_010930814) (bscW) Bordetella Bsc type III secretion system protein BscW [TTSS (VF0035) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Bordetella pertussis Tohama I]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for BscW, a critical component of the Bordetella type III secretion system (T3SS) from Bordetella pertussis. This protein is responsible for forming the translocation pore in host cell membranes, facilitating the delivery of bacterial effector proteins into target eukaryotic cells. BscW likely exhibits structural features typical of translocator proteins, with regions that undergo conformational changes upon contact with host membranes. The protein operates in concert with other T3SS components, particularly working alongside the needle complex to bridge the bacterial and host cell interfaces. Include conserved motifs essential for its interaction with chaperone proteins and other T3SS machinery components. The sequence should reflect the protein's role in establishing the translocation conduit that enables Bordetella pertussis to subvert host immune responses and establish respiratory tract colonization.

description: VFG037218(gb|WP_000983821) (basJ) acinetobactin biosynthesis protein BasJ [Acinetobactin (VF0467) - Nutritional/Metabolic factor (VFC0272)] [Acinetobacter baumannii ACICU]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the acinetobactin biosynthesis protein BasJ from Acinetobacter baumannii strain ACICU. This protein is a critical component of the acinetobactin siderophore biosynthesis pathway, which represents a key nutritional/metabolic virulence mechanism in this clinically significant multidrug-resistant pathogen. Acinetobacter baumannii employs acinetobactin as its primary siderophore to scavenge essential iron from the host environment during infection, overcoming nutritional immunity defenses. The BasJ protein functions specifically within the acinetobactin biosynthetic machinery, likely participating in the assembly or modification of the siderophore precursor molecules. Based on its role in siderophore biosynthesis, BasJ should contain conserved domains characteristic of nonribosomal peptide synthetase (NRPS) accessory proteins or siderophore biosynthesis enzymes, potentially including substrate-binding pockets, catalytic residues for acyl transfer or condensation reactions, and interaction surfaces with other Bas pathway components. The protein should exhibit structural features enabling its integration into the multi-enzyme acinetobactin biosynthesis complex, with appropriate secondary structure elements and tertiary folding to support its enzymatic function. The sequence must reflect a cytoplasmic localization with proper solubility characteristics for efficient siderophore production, while maintaining the specific functional motifs required for iron-scavenging virulence activity in the competitive host environment.

description: VFG038886(gb|WP_005314222) (lafE) LafE, flagellar hook control length protein [Lateral flagella (VF0474) - Motility (VFC0204)] [Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida A449]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for LafE, a flagellar hook control length protein from Aeromonas salmonicida subsp. salmonicida. This protein functions as a critical virulence factor by regulating the precise length of the flagellar hook structure in lateral flagella systems. Aeromonas salmonicida is a significant fish pathogen causing furunculosis, and its lateral flagella system enables surface-associated swarming motility essential for host colonization and biofilm formation. LafE operates within the flagellar assembly pathway, specifically controlling hook elongation to ensure proper flagellar function. The protein likely contains conserved domains for interaction with the flagellar export apparatus and hook structural components, featuring structural motifs that enable precise length sensing and termination of hook polymerization. The sequence should reflect a cytoplasmic protein with potential membrane-interacting regions, containing regulatory domains that monitor hook assembly progression and trigger assembly termination once optimal hook length is achieved. Include conserved residues for protein-protein interactions with other flagellar components, particularly those involved in the type III secretion-like export system of the flagellar apparatus. The structural organization should support its role as a molecular ruler or regulator that ensures the hook reaches approximately 55 nm in length before transitioning to filament assembly.

description: VFG049915(gb|WP_001142968) (hcp2/tssD2) Type VI secretion system protein, Hcp family [T6SS (VF0579) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Shigella sonnei Ss046]

This protein serves as a critical structural component of the T6SS nanomachine, forming the hexameric ring that constitutes the inner tube through which effector proteins are delivered into target cells. The protein should contain the characteristic Hcp domain architecture with conserved beta-barrel structure that enables oligomerization into stable tubular assemblies. Include the conserved residues responsible for hexamer formation and tube stacking interactions. The sequence should reflect the structural role in forming the T6SS secretion conduit, with appropriate hydrophobic patches for membrane association and charged surface residues that facilitate effector protein translocation. Consider the protein's localization to the bacterial periplasm and its assembly into the T6SS apparatus, which enables Shigella sonnei to deliver virulence effectors into host cells during infection. The generated sequence must maintain the structural integrity required for tube formation while preserving the functional motifs essential for T6SS-mediated effector delivery in this enteric pathogen.

description: VFG038378(gb|WP_011705712) (vipA) Type VI secretion system contractile sheath small subunit TssB/VipA [T6SS (VF0480) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Aeromonas hydrophila subsp. hydrophila ATCC 7966]
prompt: Design a protein sequence for the VipA protein, a core structural component of the Type VI Secretion System (T6SS) from Aeromonas hydrophila. This organism is a significant aquatic pathogen causing septicemia and wound infections in fish and humans. VipA functions as the small subunit of the contractile sheath that forms the central apparatus of the T6SS, a molecular syringe that delivers effector proteins directly into target cells. The protein should contain conserved domains characteristic of TssB/VipA family members, including helical regions that facilitate polymerization into a tubular sheath structure around the inner tube component. This sheath undergoes ATP-dependent contraction to propel the inner tube and associated effectors through the target cell membrane. The sequence should reflect structural features enabling proper oligomerization with the large sheath subunit VipB/TssC, maintaining the extended sheath conformation in the pre-firing state and facilitating rapid contraction upon activation. Key functional motifs should support interactions with the baseplate complex for sheath assembly and with the ClpV ATPase for sheath disassembly and recycling. The protein should localize to the bacterial cytoplasm and inner membrane interface, forming the dynamic contractile machinery essential for T6SS-mediated virulence.

description: VFG013292(gb|WP_105163174) (lic3A) alpha-2,3-sialyltransferase [LOS (VF0044) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Haemophilus influenzae Rd KW20]
prompt: Design a functionally accurate protein sequence for an alpha-2,3-sialyltransferase from Haemophilus influenzae strain Rd KW20, specifically the Lic3A enzyme. This virulence factor plays a critical role in immune modulation by catalyzing the transfer of sialic acid residues to terminal galactose moieties on lipooligosaccharide (LOS) structures in alpha-2,3-linkages. The resulting sialylated LOS mimics host cell surface glycans, enabling molecular mimicry that evades complement-mediated killing and neutrophil phagocytosis, thereby enhancing bacterial survival in the human respiratory tract. The enzyme should contain conserved glycosyltransferase family 29 (GT29) domains, including the characteristic DXD motif essential for manganese cofactor binding and catalytic activity. Structural features should include a typical GT-B fold with dual Rossmann-like domains that facilitate nucleotide-sugar donor (CMP-Neu5Ac) binding and acceptor substrate recognition. The protein should localize to the bacterial periplasmic space or outer membrane interface to access LOS substrates. Key functional regions must include substrate binding pockets that specifically recognize terminal galactose on LOS and CMP-Neu5Ac, with appropriate transmembrane segments or signal peptides for proper cellular localization. The enzyme should demonstrate optimal activity at physiological conditions relevant to human nasopharyngeal colonization.

description: VFG000540(gb|NP_461799) (sptP) type III secretion system effector SptP, tyrosine phosphatase and GTPase-activating protein [TTSS-1 secreted effectors (VF0949) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica serovar Typhimurium str. LT2]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for SptP, a critical bifunctional type III secretion system effector protein from Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium. This virulence factor represents a sophisticated molecular weapon that Salmonella injects directly into host intestinal epithelial cells via the SPI-1-encoded T3SS apparatus. The protein must contain two distinct enzymatic domains that function in coordinated host cell manipulation: an N-terminal region encoding a tyrosine phosphatase domain that specifically dephosphorylates host MAPK signaling components to suppress pro-inflammatory responses, and a C-terminal domain exhibiting GTPase-activating protein (GAP) activity that targets host Rho-family GTPases (particularly Cdc42 and Rac1) to reverse actin cytoskeleton rearrangements initiated by other Salmonella effectors. The protein should feature characteristic T3SS secretion signals, likely including an unstructured N-terminal region that facilitates translocation through the injectisome needle complex. The tyrosine phosphatase domain should contain the conserved HCX5R active site motif characteristic of protein tyrosine phosphatases, while the GAP domain should display the arginine finger motif essential for catalyzing GTP hydrolysis in target GTPases. The protein should adopt a modular architecture with flexible linker regions between functional domains to allow independent catalytic activities. The sequence must reflect optimal codon usage for Salmonella expression and include appropriate molecular features for efficient secretion through the T3SS machinery, ultimately enabling precise temporal regulation of host cell signaling pathways to facilitate bacterial invasion and intracellular survival.

description: VFG048995(gb|WP_015874986) (rmpA) regulator of mucoid phenotype RmpA [RmpA (VF0570) - Regulation (VFC0301)] [Klebsiella pneumoniae subsp. pneumoniae NTUH-K2044]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for the RmpA protein, a key transcriptional regulator of mucoid phenotype in Klebsiella pneumoniae. This protein functions as a central virulence determinant by activating the expression of capsular polysaccharide biosynthesis genes, leading to hypermucoviscosity—a hallmark trait of hypervirulent K. pneumoniae strains that enhances resistance to phagocytosis and serum killing. RmpA is predicted to contain a DNA-binding domain, likely of the winged helix-turn-helix or LuxR-type, enabling specific recognition of promoter regions upstream of capsule operons. It may also feature dimerization motifs, such as coiled-coil regions or leucine zippers, facilitating oligomerization for enhanced transcriptional activation. The protein is localized to the cytoplasm and functions as a positive regulator within the Rcs phosphorelay system, interacting with other regulatory components to amplify capsule production. Structurally, RmpA should exhibit a compact, globular fold with surface-exposed basic residues for DNA backbone contacts and hydrophobic patches for protein-protein interactions. The sequence must include conserved residues for DNA binding, such as arginine or lysine for phosphate interactions and aromatic residues for base stacking, along with potential phosphorylation sites for regulatory modulation. Ensure the sequence reflects a stable, soluble cytoplasmic protein with appropriate length and domain organization to support its role in transcriptional regulation and virulence enhancement.

description: VFG002450(gb|WP_004533397) (bipB) Type III secretion system translocator protein BipB [Bsa T3SS (VF0428) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Burkholderia pseudomallei K96243]
prompt: Generate the amino acid sequence for BipB, a critical Type III secretion system translocator protein from Burkholderia pseudomallei. This protein functions as an essential virulence factor in the Bsa T3SS effector delivery system, forming part of the translocation pore complex that enables direct injection of bacterial effector proteins into host cells. BipB should contain conserved domains characteristic of T3SS translocators, including transmembrane regions for membrane insertion and pore formation, as well as domains that facilitate interaction with partner translocator proteins to assemble the functional translocation apparatus. Structurally, BipB should possess features enabling oligomerization to form the translocation channel, with specific motifs that recognize and guide effector proteins through the secretion apparatus. The sequence must reflect the protein's role in breaching host cell membranes during infection, facilitating the delivery of virulence factors that enable intracellular survival and pathogenesis of this dangerous bacterial pathogen.

description: VFG033604(gb|WP_000444178) (glrA) type III secretion system LEE transcriptional regulator GrlA [TTSS (VF0172) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Escherichia coli O127:H6 str. E2348/69]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for GrlA, a master transcriptional regulator from the enteropathogenic Escherichia coli O127:H6 strain E2348/69. This protein functions as the central controller of the Locus of Enterocyte Effacement (LEE) pathogenicity island, which encodes the complete Type III Secretion System (T3SS) apparatus and associated effector proteins. GrlA operates as a key virulence determinant by directly activating transcription of LEE operons, including those encoding the structural components of the T3SS needle complex, translocon proteins, and effector molecules essential for attaching and effacing lesion formation on intestinal epithelial cells. The protein should contain a conserved DNA-binding domain with helix-turn-helix motifs characteristic of transcriptional activators, enabling specific recognition of LEE promoter regions. It likely forms regulatory complexes with its partner protein GrlR, which modulates GrlA activity through protein-protein interactions. The sequence should reflect optimal structural features for nuclear localization and DNA binding, including appropriate surface charge distribution for promoter recognition and dimerization interfaces for functional oligomerization. Include conserved residues critical for DNA contact and transcriptional activation function, ensuring the generated sequence maintains the precise molecular architecture required for coordinating the hierarchical expression cascade that establishes bacterial colonization and virulence in the human gastrointestinal tract.

description: VFG048055(gb|WP_003022145) (pdpE) Type VI secretion system secreted protein PdpE [T6SS (VF0544) - Effector delivery system (VFC0086)] [Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis SCHU S4]
prompt: Generate the complete amino acid sequence for PdpE, a critical Type VI secretion system (T6SS) effector protein from the highly virulent bacterial pathogen Francisella tularensis subsp. tularensis strain SCHU S4. This protein functions as a secreted virulence factor that is translocated into host cells via the T6SS apparatus to subvert host immune defenses and facilitate intracellular survival. PdpE likely contains conserved domains characteristic of T6SS effectors, including a C-terminal toxin or enzymatic domain responsible for its specific host-targeting activity and an N-terminal secretion signal recognized by the T6SS machinery. The protein should exhibit structural features enabling its encapsulation within the T6SS phage tail-like tube, such as a compact globular fold with surface-exposed motifs for interaction with T6SS structural components like Hep or VgrG. Infer potential functional motifs based on Francisella T6SS effectors, which often target host cell processes like membrane integrity, cytoskeletal dynamics, or signaling pathways. The sequence must reflect a soluble, secreted protein optimized for delivery into eukaryotic cells, with appropriate physicochemical properties for stability in both bacterial and host environments, and include any characteristic sequence patterns associated with Francisella T6SS effector families.

description: VFG002554(gb|WP_011205222) (gmhA) phosphoheptose isomerase [Capsule I (VF0436) - Immune modulation (VFC0258)] [Burkholderia pseudomallei K96243]
prompt: Design a functional phosphoheptose isomerase enzyme from the highly virulent bacterial pathogen Burkholderia pseudomallei. This enzyme, encoded by the gmhA gene, serves as a critical virulence factor by catalyzing the first committed step in the biosynthesis of heptose sugars for the bacterial capsule. The capsule is a major immune evasion structure that protects the bacterium from host phagocytosis and complement-mediated killing. The enzyme functions in the early stages of the lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and capsule biosynthesis pathway, specifically isomerizing sedoheptulose-7-phosphate to D-glycero-D-manno-heptose-7-phosphate. This reaction is essential for the formation of the core oligosaccharide and capsule polysaccharide, both crucial for bacterial survival in hostile host environments. The protein should contain the conserved sugar isomerase (SIS) domain characteristic of the GmhA protein family, with the active site residues responsible for the isomerization reaction properly positioned. The enzyme likely functions as a homodimer or homotetramer, exhibiting the classic (β/α)8 TIM barrel fold common to many sugar isomerases. Key structural features should include the substrate-binding pocket that accommodates the seven-carbon sugar phosphate and the catalytic residues that facilitate the aldose-ketose isomerization. The protein should be cytoplasmic-localized since it operates in the central metabolic pathway for capsule precursor synthesis. Design this enzyme to be highly specific for its heptose substrate while maintaining the structural stability required for function in the intracellular environment of this dangerous Category B select agent pathogen.
